doc.title: hmmer

description.text: HMMER is an implementation of profile HMM methods for sensitive database searches using multiple sequence alignments as queries.

doc.reference: Eddy, S. R. (1998). Profile hidden Markov models. Bioinformatics, 14:755-763.
Eddy, S. R. (2008). A probabilistic model of local sequence alignment that simplifies statistical significance estimation. PLoS Comput. Biol., 4:e1000069

description.text: Iteratively search protein sequence(s) against a protein database

interface.label: Choose a protein sequence database Choose a database Select Alu repeats from REPBASE nrprot: NCBI non-redundant Genbank CDS translations+PDB+Swissprot+PIR Protein Data Bank NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) Database last release NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) updates RefSeq (last release + updates) sbase: annotated domains sequences uniprot: Universal Protein Resource (sprot+treml) uniprot_sprot: Universal Protein Resource (SwissProt part) uniprot_trembl: Universal Protein Resource (TrEmbl part) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 90) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 50) Virus Pathogen Resource Genbank : Whole Genome Shotgun

Maximum number of iterations (-N)?
Set the maximum number of iterations (default is 5). If =1, the result is equivalent to a phmmer search.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default, output for each iteration appears on stdout in a somewhat human readable, somewhat parseable format. These options allow redirecting that output or saving additional kinds of output to files, including checkpoint files for each iteration.

xhtml:div.label:
Direct output to file (-o)?
Yes No
Direct the main "human-readable" output to a file instead of the default stdout.

Save multiple alignment of hits to file (-A)?
Yes No
After the final iteration, save an annotated multiple alignment of all hits satisfying inclusion thresholds (also including the original query) to a file (Stockholm format).

Save parseable table of per-sequence hits to file (--tblout)?
Yes No
After the final iteration, save a tabular summary of top sequence hits to a file in a readily parseable, columnar, whitespace-delimited format.

Save parseable table of per-domain hits to file (--domtblout)?
Yes No
After the final iteration, save a tabular summary of top domain hits to a file in a readily parseable, columnar, whitespace-delimited format.

Save HMM checkpoints (--chkhmm)?
Yes No
At the start of each iteration, checkpoint the query HMM, saving it to a file named phmmer-n.hmm where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).

Save alignment checkpoints (--chkali)?
Yes No
At the end of each iteration, checkpoint an alignment of all domains satisfying inclusion thresholds (e.g. what will become the query HMM for the next iteration), saving it to a file named phmmer-n.sto in Stockholm format, where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).

Don't output alignments, so output is smaller (--noali)?
Yes No
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)?
Yes No
Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.
Max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)

fieldset.legend: Controlling single sequence scoring in first iteration?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default, the first iteration uses a search model constructed from a single query sequence. This model is constructed using a standard 20x20 substitution matrix for residue probabilities, and two additional parameters for position-independent gap open and gap extend probabilities. These options allow the default single-sequence scoring parameters to be changed.

xhtml:div.label:
Gap open probability (--popen)?
Set the gap open probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <0.5. Default value = 0.02.

Gap extend probability (--pextend)?
Set the gap extend probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <1. Default value: 0.4.

Substitution score matrix (--mxfile)?
BLOSUM62 BLOSUM30 BLOSUM35 BLOSUM40 BLOSUM45 BLOSUM50 BLOSUM55 BLOSUM60 BLOSUM65 BLOSUM70 BLOSUM75 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM85 BLOSUM90 PAM10 PAM20 PAM30 PAM40 PAM50 PAM60 PAM70 PAM80 PAM90 PAM100 PAM110 PAM120 PAM130 PAM140 PAM150 PAM160 PAM170 PAM180 PAM190 PAM200 PAM210 PAM220 PAM230 PAM240 PAM250 PAM260 PAM270 PAM280 PAM290 PAM300 PAM310 PAM320 PAM330 PAM340 PAM350 PAM360 PAM370 PAM380 PAM390 PAM400
To obtain residue alignment probabilities from a substitution matrix. The default score matrix is BLOSUM62

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: "Reporting" thresholds control which hits are reported in output files (the main output, --tblout, and -- domtblout). In each iteration, sequence hits and domain hits are ranked by statistical significance (E-value) and output is generated in two sections called "per-target" and "per-domain" output.
The following options allow you to change the default E-value reporting thresholds, or to use bit score thresholds instead.

xhtml:div.label:
Thresholds for Sequences: E-value (-E)?
Report sequences <= this E-value threshold in per-sequence output. [Default value: 10].

Score (-T)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of -E is ignored). Report sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold in output. By default this option is unset.

Thresholds for Domains: E-value (--domE)?
Report domains with conditional E-values < or = this E-value threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit.[Default value: 10]

Score (--domT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-domain output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --domE is ignored). Report domains with a bit score of >= this score threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. By default this option is unset.

fieldset.legend: Controlling significance thresholds for inclusion in next round?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Inclusion thresholds control which hits are included in the final multiple alignment (if the -A option is used) and which hits actually get used in the next iteration.

xhtml:div.label:
Thresholds for Sequences: E-value (--incE)?
Include sequences with E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option). The default is 0.001.

Score (--incT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incE is ignored). Include sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

Thresholds for Domains: E-value (--incdomE)?
Include domains with conditional E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option), in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. The default is 0.001.

Score (--incdomT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-domain inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incdomE is ignored). Include domains with a bit score of > = this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: HMMER3 searches are accelerated in a three-step filter pipeline:
- the MSV filter (the fastest and most approximate),
- the Viterbi filter,
- and the Forward filter (full Forward scoring algorithm, slowest but most accurate),
+ There is also a "bias filter" step between MSV and Viterbi.
Targets that pass all the steps in the acceleration pipeline are then subjected to "postprocessing" (domain identification and scoring using the Forward/Backward algorithm).
Essentially the only free parameters that control HMMER's heuristic filters are the P-value thresholds controlling the expected fraction of non-homologous sequences that pass the filters.
- Setting the default thresholds higher will pass a higher proportion of non-homologous sequence, increasing sensitivity at the expense of speed,
- Setting lower P-value thresholds will pass a smaller proportion, decreasing sensitivity and increasing speed,
- Setting a filter's P-value threshold to 1.0 means it will passing all sequences, and effectively disables the filter.
Changing filter thresholds only removes or includes targets from consideration; it does not alter bit scores, E-values, or alignments, all of which are determined solely in "postprocessing".

xhtml:div.label:
Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)?
Yes No
Maximum sensitivity. Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/ Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity slightly, at a large cost in speed.

Stage 1 (MSV) threshold: (--F1)?
First filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring non-homologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

Stage 2 (Vit) threshold: (--F2)?
Second filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

Stage 3 (Fwd) threshold: (--F3)?
Third filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

Turn off composition bias filter (--nobias)?
Yes No
Turn off the bias filter increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity).
Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These options control how consensus columns are defined in multiple alignments when building profiles. By default, jackhmmer always includes your original query sequence in the alignment result at every iteration, and consensus positions are defined by that query sequence: that is, a default jackhmmer profile is always the same length as your original query, at every iteration.

xhtml:div.label:
Quickly and heuristically determine the architecture of the model (--fast)?
Yes No
Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as consensus/opposed to gaps. (See below for the --symfrac option.) This option may have undesirable effects in jackhmmer, because a profile could iteratively walk in sequence space away from your original query, leaving few or no consensus columns corresponding to its residues.

Symbol fraction controlling --fast construction (--symfrac)?
Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions).
- Setting this to 1.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases.
- Setting it to 0.0 is a bad idea, because no columns will be assigned as consensus, and you will get a model of zero length.

Threshold to tag sequence as a fragment (--fragthresh)?
We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length is less than a fraction threshold times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

fieldset.legend: Controlling relative weights and effective sequence number in models after first iteration?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Whenever a profile is built from a multiple alignment, HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation.

After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number (eff_nseq). This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that.

xhtml:div.label:
Relative weights in models?
Henikoff position-based weights (--wpb) Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia tree weights (--wgsc) Henikoff simple filter weights (--wblosum) Don't do any relative weighting (--wnone)
These option controls which ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm gets used:
- Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
- Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].
- Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915,1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid option) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
- No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight.

Set identity cutoff in case of Henikoff simple filter weights (--wblosum) selection (--wid)?
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62.

Effective sequence number in models?
Adjust effective sequence number to achieve relative entropy target (--eent) Effective sequence number is the number of single linkage clusters (--eclust) No effective sequence number weighting: just use nseq (--enone)
Choice between:
- eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default. This method reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position.
- eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it is for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.
- enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models.
Effective sequence number for all model (--eset)

Minimum relative entropy/position target for --eent (--ere)?
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

Sigma parameter for --eent (--esigma)?
Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

Fractional Identity cutoff for --eclust (--eid)?
Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

fieldset.legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 1 - MSV Gumbel mu fit?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.

xhtml:div.label:
Length of sequences (--EmL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

Number of sequences (--EmN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

fieldset.legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 2 - Viterbi Gumbel mu fit?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.

xhtml:div.label:
Length of sequences (--EvL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

Number of sequences (--EvN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

fieldset.legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 3 - Forward exponential tail tau fit?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.

xhtml:div.label:
Length of sequences (--EfL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.

Number of sequences (--EfN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.

Tail mass (--Eft)?
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)?
Yes No
Turn off the "null2" score corrections for biased composition.

Number of comparisons done, for E-value calculation (-Z)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

Number of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

Set Random Number Generator seed to (--seed)?
Seed the random number generator with this, an integer >= 0. The default seed is 42.
If >0, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results.
If = 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the maximum number of iterations (default is 5). If =1, the result is equivalent to a phmmer search.
Direct the main "human-readable" output to a file instead of the default stdout.
After the final iteration, save an annotated multiple alignment of all hits satisfying inclusion thresholds (also including the original query) to a file (Stockholm format).
After the final iteration, save a tabular summary of top sequence hits to a file in a readily parseable, columnar, whitespace-delimited format.
After the final iteration, save a tabular summary of top domain hits to a file in a readily parseable, columnar, whitespace-delimited format.
At the start of each iteration, checkpoint the query HMM, saving it to a file named phmmer-n.hmm where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).

At the end of each iteration, checkpoint an alignment of all domains satisfying inclusion thresholds (e.g. what will become the query HMM for the next iteration), saving it to a file named phmmer-n.sto in Stockholm format, where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).
Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences.
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling single sequence scoring in first iteration

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the gap open probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <0.5. Default value = 0.02.
Set the gap extend probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <1. Default value: 0.4.
To obtain residue alignment probabilities from a substitution matrix. The default score matrix is BLOSUM62
Report sequences <= this E-value threshold in per-sequence output. [Default value: 10].

Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of -E is ignored). Report sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold in output. By default this option is unset.
Report domains with conditional E-values < or = this E-value threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit.[Default value: 10]

Use a bit score threshold for per-domain output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --domE is ignored). Report domains with a bit score of >= this score threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling significance thresholds for inclusion in next round

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Include sequences with E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option). The default is 0.001.

Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incE is ignored). Include sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

Include domains with conditional E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option), in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. The default is 0.001.

Use a bit score threshold for per-domain inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incdomE is ignored). Include domains with a bit score of > = this score threshold. By default this option is unset.
Maximum sensitivity. Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/ Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity slightly, at a large cost in speed.
First filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring non-homologous targets are expected to pass the filter.
Second filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.
Third filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

Turn off the bias filter increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity).

Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as consensus/opposed to gaps. (See below for the --symfrac option.) This option may have undesirable effects in jackhmmer, because a profile could iteratively walk in sequence space away from your original query, leaving few or no consensus columns corresponding to its residues.

Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions).
- Setting this to 1.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases.
- Setting it to 0.0 is a bad idea, because no columns will be assigned as consensus, and you will get a model of zero length.

We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length is less than a fraction threshold times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling relative weights and effective sequence number in models after first iteration

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These option controls which ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm gets used:
- Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
- Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

- Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915,1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid option) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
- No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight.
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62.
Choice between:

- eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default. This method reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position.

- eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it is for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

- enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models.
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.
Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 1 - MSV Gumbel mu fit

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 2 - Viterbi Gumbel mu fit

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 3 - Forward exponential tail tau fit

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.
Turn off the "null2" score corrections for biased composition.
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.
Seed the random number generator with this, an integer >= 0. The default seed is 42.
If >0, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results.
If = 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command.

Yes No
At the end of each iteration, checkpoint an alignment of all domains satisfying inclusion thresholds (e.g. what will become the query HMM for the next iteration), saving it to a file named phmmer-n.sto in Stockholm format, where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: At the end of each iteration, checkpoint an alignment of all domains satisfying inclusion thresholds (e.g. what will become the query HMM for the next iteration), saving it to a file named phmmer-n.sto in Stockholm format, where n is the iteration number (from 1..N).

parameter.name: acc
parameter.prompt: Prefer accessions over names in output (--acc)

comment.text: Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences.

parameter.name: noali
parameter.prompt: Don't output alignments, so output is smaller (--noali)

comment.text: Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

interface.label:
Don't output alignments, so output is smaller (--noali)?
Yes No
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

parameter.name: notextw
parameter.prompt: Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)

comment.text: Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

interface.label:
Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)?
Yes No
Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

parameter.name: textw
parameter.prompt: Max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)

interface.label: Max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)

paragraph.name: scoringsys
paragraph.prompt: Controlling single sequence scoring in first iteration

comment.text: By default, the first iteration uses a search model constructed from a single query sequence. This model is constructed using a standard 20x20 substitution matrix for residue probabilities, and two additional parameters for position-independent gap open and gap extend probabilities. These options allow the default single-sequence scoring parameters to be changed.
Set the gap open probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <0.5. Default value = 0.02.

interface.label:
Gap open probability (--popen)?
Set the gap open probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <0.5. Default value = 0.02.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the gap open probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <0.5. Default value = 0.02.

comment.text: Set the gap extend probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <1. Default value: 0.4.

interface.label:
Gap extend probability (--pextend)?
Set the gap extend probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <1. Default value: 0.4.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the gap extend probability for a single sequence query model. This probability has to be >= 0 and <1. Default value: 0.4.

comment.text: To obtain residue alignment probabilities from a substitution matrix. The default score matrix is BLOSUM62

interface.label:
Substitution score matrix (--mxfile)?
BLOSUM62 BLOSUM30 BLOSUM35 BLOSUM40 BLOSUM45 BLOSUM50 BLOSUM55 BLOSUM60 BLOSUM65 BLOSUM70 BLOSUM75 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM85 BLOSUM90 PAM10 PAM20 PAM30 PAM40 PAM50 PAM60 PAM70 PAM80 PAM90 PAM100 PAM110 PAM120 PAM130 PAM140 PAM150 PAM160 PAM170 PAM180 PAM190 PAM200 PAM210 PAM220 PAM230 PAM240 PAM250 PAM260 PAM270 PAM280 PAM290 PAM300 PAM310 PAM320 PAM330 PAM340 PAM350 PAM360 PAM370 PAM380 PAM390 PAM400
To obtain residue alignment probabilities from a substitution matrix. The default score matrix is BLOSUM62

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: To obtain residue alignment probabilities from a substitution matrix. The default score matrix is BLOSUM62

comment.text: "Reporting" thresholds control which hits are reported in output files (the main output, --tblout, and -- domtblout). In each iteration, sequence hits and domain hits are ranked by statistical significance (E-value) and output is generated in two sections called "per-target" and "per-domain" output.
The following options allow you to change the default E-value reporting thresholds, or to use bit score thresholds instead.
Report sequences <= this E-value threshold in per-sequence output. [Default value: 10].

interface.label:
Thresholds for Sequences: E-value (-E)?
Report sequences <= this E-value threshold in per-sequence output. [Default value: 10].

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Report sequences <= this E-value threshold in per-sequence output. [Default value: 10].

comment.text: Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of -E is ignored). Report sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold in output. By default this option is unset.

interface.label:
Score (-T)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of -E is ignored). Report sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold in output. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of -E is ignored). Report sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold in output. By default this option is unset.

format.code: ("", " --domE " + str(value)) [ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Report domains with conditional E-values < or = this E-value threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit.[Default value: 10]

interface.label:
Thresholds for Domains: E-value (--domE)?
Report domains with conditional E-values < or = this E-value threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit.[Default value: 10]

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Report domains with conditional E-values < or = this E-value threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit.[Default value: 10]

comment.text: Use a bit score threshold for per-domain output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --domE is ignored). Report domains with a bit score of >= this score threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. By default this option is unset.

interface.label:
Score (--domT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-domain output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --domE is ignored). Report domains with a bit score of >= this score threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use a bit score threshold for per-domain output instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --domE is ignored). Report domains with a bit score of >= this score threshold in per-domain output, in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. By default this option is unset.

paragraph.name: inclusion_A
paragraph.prompt: Controlling significance thresholds for inclusion in next round

comment.text: Inclusion thresholds control which hits are included in the final multiple alignment (if the -A option is used) and which hits actually get used in the next iteration.

format.code: ("", " --incE " + str(value)) [ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Include sequences with E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option). The default is 0.001.

interface.label:
Thresholds for Sequences: E-value (--incE)?
Include sequences with E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option). The default is 0.001.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Include sequences with E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option). The default is 0.001.

comment.text: Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incE is ignored). Include sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

interface.label:
Score (--incT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incE is ignored). Include sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use a bit score threshold for per-sequence inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incE is ignored). Include sequences with a bit score of >= this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

format.code: ("", " --incdomE " + str(value)) [ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Include domains with conditional E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option), in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. The default is 0.001.

interface.label:
Thresholds for Domains: E-value (--incdomE)?
Include domains with conditional E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option), in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. The default is 0.001.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Include domains with conditional E-values <= this E-value threshold in subsequent iteration or final alignment output (-A option), in addition to the top-scoring domain per significant sequence hit. The default is 0.001.

comment.text: Use a bit score threshold for per-domain inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incdomE is ignored). Include domains with a bit score of > = this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

interface.label:
Score (--incdomT)?
Use a bit score threshold for per-domain inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incdomE is ignored). Include domains with a bit score of > = this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use a bit score threshold for per-domain inclusion instead of an E-value threshold (any setting of --incdomE is ignored). Include domains with a bit score of > = this score threshold. By default this option is unset.

comment.text: HMMER3 searches are accelerated in a three-step filter pipeline:
- the MSV filter (the fastest and most approximate),
- the Viterbi filter,
- and the Forward filter (full Forward scoring algorithm, slowest but most accurate),
+ There is also a "bias filter" step between MSV and Viterbi.
Targets that pass all the steps in the acceleration pipeline are then subjected to "postprocessing" (domain identification and scoring using the Forward/Backward algorithm).
Essentially the only free parameters that control HMMER's heuristic filters are the P-value thresholds controlling the expected fraction of non-homologous sequences that pass the filters.
- Setting the default thresholds higher will pass a higher proportion of non-homologous sequence, increasing sensitivity at the expense of speed,
- Setting lower P-value thresholds will pass a smaller proportion, decreasing sensitivity and increasing speed,
- Setting a filter's P-value threshold to 1.0 means it will passing all sequences, and effectively disables the filter.
Changing filter thresholds only removes or includes targets from consideration; it does not alter bit scores, E-values, or alignments, all of which are determined solely in "postprocessing".

parameter.name: max
parameter.prompt: Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)

comment.text: Maximum sensitivity. Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/ Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity slightly, at a large cost in speed.

interface.label:
Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)?
Yes No
Maximum sensitivity. Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/ Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity slightly, at a large cost in speed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Maximum sensitivity. Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/ Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity slightly, at a large cost in speed.

comment.text: First filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring non-homologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

interface.label:
Stage 1 (MSV) threshold: (--F1)?
First filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring non-homologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: First filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring non-homologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

comment.text: Second filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

interface.label:
Stage 2 (Vit) threshold: (--F2)?
Second filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Second filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

comment.text: Third filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

interface.label:
Stage 3 (Fwd) threshold: (--F3)?
Third filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Third filter threshold; set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

comment.text: Turn off the bias filter increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity).

Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

interface.label:
Turn off composition bias filter (--nobias)?
Yes No
Turn off the bias filter increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity).
Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn off the bias filter increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity).

Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

comment.text: These options control how consensus columns are defined in multiple alignments when building profiles. By default, jackhmmer always includes your original query sequence in the alignment result at every iteration, and consensus positions are defined by that query sequence: that is, a default jackhmmer profile is always the same length as your original query, at every iteration.

parameter.name: fast
parameter.prompt: Quickly and heuristically determine the architecture of the model (--fast)

comment.text: Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as consensus/opposed to gaps. (See below for the --symfrac option.) This option may have undesirable effects in jackhmmer, because a profile could iteratively walk in sequence space away from your original query, leaving few or no consensus columns corresponding to its residues.

interface.label:
Quickly and heuristically determine the architecture of the model (--fast)?
Yes No
Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as consensus/opposed to gaps. (See below for the --symfrac option.) This option may have undesirable effects in jackhmmer, because a profile could iteratively walk in sequence space away from your original query, leaving few or no consensus columns corresponding to its residues.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as consensus/opposed to gaps. (See below for the --symfrac option.) This option may have undesirable effects in jackhmmer, because a profile could iteratively walk in sequence space away from your original query, leaving few or no consensus columns corresponding to its residues.

comment.text: Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions).
- Setting this to 1.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases.
- Setting it to 0.0 is a bad idea, because no columns will be assigned as consensus, and you will get a model of zero length.

interface.label:
Symbol fraction controlling --fast construction (--symfrac)?
Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions).
- Setting this to 1.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases.
- Setting it to 0.0 is a bad idea, because no columns will be assigned as consensus, and you will get a model of zero length.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions).
- Setting this to 1.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases.
- Setting it to 0.0 is a bad idea, because no columns will be assigned as consensus, and you will get a model of zero length.

parameter.name: fragthresh
parameter.prompt: Threshold to tag sequence as a fragment (--fragthresh)

comment.text: We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length is less than a fraction threshold times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

interface.label:
Threshold to tag sequence as a fragment (--fragthresh)?
We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length is less than a fraction threshold times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length is less than a fraction threshold times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

paragraph.name: w_option
paragraph.prompt: Controlling relative weights and effective sequence number in models after first iteration

comment.text: Whenever a profile is built from a multiple alignment, HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation.

After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number (eff_nseq). This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that.
These option controls which ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm gets used:
- Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
- Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

- Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915,1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid option) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
- No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight.

interface.label:
Relative weights in models?
Henikoff position-based weights (--wpb) Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia tree weights (--wgsc) Henikoff simple filter weights (--wblosum) Don't do any relative weighting (--wnone)
These option controls which ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm gets used:
- Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
- Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].
- Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915,1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid option) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
- No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These option controls which ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm gets used:
- Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
- Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

- Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915,1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid option) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
- No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight.

parameter.name: wid
parameter.prompt: Set identity cutoff in case of Henikoff simple filter weights (--wblosum) selection (--wid)

comment.text: Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62.

interface.label:
Set identity cutoff in case of Henikoff simple filter weights (--wblosum) selection (--wid)?
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62.

velem.label: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve relative entropy target (--eent)
Effective sequence number is the number of single linkage clusters (--eclust)
No effective sequence number weighting: just use nseq (--enone)

comment.text: Choice between:

- eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default. This method reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position.

- eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it is for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

- enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models.

interface.label:
Effective sequence number in models?
Adjust effective sequence number to achieve relative entropy target (--eent) Effective sequence number is the number of single linkage clusters (--eclust) No effective sequence number weighting: just use nseq (--enone)
Choice between:
- eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default. This method reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position.
- eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it is for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.
- enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Choice between:

- eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default. This method reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position.

- eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it is for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

- enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models.

parameter.name: eff_snum
parameter.prompt: Effective sequence number for all model (--eset)

interface.label: Effective sequence number for all model (--eset)

comment.text: Set the minimum relative entropy/position target. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

interface.label:
Minimum relative entropy/position target for --eent (--ere)?
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the minimum relative entropy/position target. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

format.code: ( "" , " --esigma " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

interface.label:
Sigma parameter for --eent (--esigma)?
Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

comment.text: Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

interface.label:
Fractional Identity cutoff for --eclust (--eid)?
Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

paragraph.name: MSV
paragraph.prompt: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 1 - MSV Gumbel mu fit

comment.text: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Length of sequences (--EmL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

comment.text: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Number of sequences (--EmN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

paragraph.name: Ecalibration2
paragraph.prompt: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 2 - Viterbi Gumbel mu fit

comment.text: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Length of sequences (--EvL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

comment.text: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Number of sequences (--EvN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

paragraph.name: Ecalibration3
paragraph.prompt: Controlling E-value calibration for Stage 3 - Forward exponential tail tau fit

comment.text: Estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores requires three short random sequence simulations.
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.

interface.label:
Length of sequences (--EfL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.

comment.text: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Number of sequences (--EfN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.

comment.text: Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

interface.label:
Tail mass (--Eft)?
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

parameter.name: nonull
parameter.prompt: Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)

comment.text: Turn off the "null2" score corrections for biased composition.

interface.label:
Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)?
Yes No
Turn off the "null2" score corrections for biased composition.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn off the "null2" score corrections for biased composition.

parameter.name: z
parameter.prompt: Number of comparisons done, for E-value calculation (-Z)

comment.text: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

interface.label:
Number of comparisons done, for E-value calculation (-Z)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

parameter.name: d_z
parameter.prompt: Number of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)

comment.text: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

interface.label:
Number of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is this number, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.prompt: Set Random Number Generator seed to (--seed)

comment.text: Seed the random number generator with this, an integer >= 0. The default seed is 42.
If >0, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results.
If = 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command.

interface.label:
Set Random Number Generator seed to (--seed)?
Seed the random number generator with this, an integer >= 0. The default seed is 42.
If >0, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results.
If = 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Seed the random number generator with this, an integer >= 0. The default seed is 42.
If >0, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results.
If = 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command.
